title: HTML td element with a row header (th[scope="row"])
description: This test verifies that the row header is announced for associated td elements when the scope="row" attribute is used.
sr_instructions: Use the screen reader to navigate to the target cell. The target cell contains the text "target"
The test passes if the row header "row one header" was announced with the target cell. If some commands work and others do not, the test should be marked as 'partial support'.

history.message: Sample data has been added. This data has not been verified.

output.output: Row 1 of 2 Row one header, target

safari.notes: When the table is first announced by VO, it states that you can "navigate the cells within this table by pressing Control-Option, and then Up Arrow, Down Arrow, Left Arrow, or Right Arrow". When navigating by Control+Option + Left/Right Arrows, the test fails. The test passes when navigating by Control+Option Up/Down Arrows.

output.output: target, non-selected, row 1 of 2 column 2 of 2
target, non-selected, row 1 of 2 column 2 of 2

edge.notes:
Navigating forwards and backwards through the table via Caps Lock + Right/Left Arrows made no difference in output.
Navigating with table specific commands improves the experience, however the target element fails the test. No header is found when Caps Lock + F10 (read row header) is pressed while on the target element. However, the correct row header is announced for row 2 column 2. While the target element fails, it appears that the scope=row attribute is sometimes supported.

firefox.notes: The row header was not announced while moving forward through the table (using down arrow). However if reading backwards through the table (up arrow) the row header was read.
